snippet: Perhaps more so than in any other place in the city, the loss of power for people living in public housing projects has forced a return to a basic existence.
abstract: Hurricane Sandy has had an especially powerful effect on residents of New York City's public housing, as loss of power, fresh water, and other necessities returns thousands to a primal existence; many of the city's 400,000 such residents defied evacuation orders and now make up a city within a city that has increasingly desperate needs.

byline.original: By CARA BUCKLEY and MICHAEL WILSON
byline.contributor: Colin Moynihan and Mosi Secret contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Perhaps more so than in any other place in the city, the loss of power for people living in public housing projects has forced a return to a basic existence.

headline.seo: In Public Housing After Hurricane Sandy, Fear, Misery and Heroism
headline.main: In New York’s Public Housing, Fear Creeps In With the Dark
headline.print_headline: In City’s Public Housing Projects, Fear Creeps In With the Dark
